summary: Today felt slower than I would’ve liked. The iron bottleneck is starting to weigh on everything. Every machine, every expansion, every research decision seems to compete for the same limited stack of plates.

I spent a good chunk of time manually mining rocks just to keep the stone reserves afloat while iron plate is slowly being produced. Science keeps eating through stone faster than I expect. It’s frustrating to watch stockpiles vanish almost as soon as they’re created.

I researched Fluid Handling today to unlock underground pipes. Coal processing is not simple — there are multiple fluids and gases involved now and underground pipes help moving necessary fluid from one location to another.
I also picked up Basic Water Processing since steam production will require it soon. The infrastructure is becoming layered and interconnected. Nothing stands alone anymore.
After that, I stopped science entirely. Iron just can’t support both research and expansion right now. It feels wrong to halt progress, but scaling iron production has to come first.
The logistics mall is technically finished, but it barely runs. It constantly starves for iron, stuttering between craft cycles. I also haven’t set up ash output yet, which is becoming a problem.
I cleared several thousand units of ash from machines by hand. Again. It’s becoming routine maintenance, and it’s eating time I’d rather spend expanding.
Once iron stabilizes, I need to automate ash removal and route everything to a central location. I can’t keep babysitting machines like this.
I had planned to move into coke and carbolic oil production, but that’ll have to wait. For now, everything hinges on fixing the iron situation.

status.resource: Iron critically bottlenecked; stone tight but manageable through manual mining.
status.production: Mall structure complete but underfed; expansion efforts redirected to iron scaling.
status.science: Fluid Handling and Basic Water Processing researched; science paused pending iron stabilization.
status.defense: Perimeter holding; ongoing reinforcement of weak sections.
